title: Elevated Estradiol and Testosterone Levels and Risk for Breast Cancer
abstract: Letters2 November 1999Elevated Estradiol and Testosterone Levels and Risk for Breast CancerHerbert Yu, MD, PhD, Eleftherios P. Diamandis, MD, PhD, and Barry Hoffman, PhDHerbert Yu, MD, PhDLouisiana State University Medical Center; Shreveport, LA 71130-3932 (Yu)Mount Sinai Hospital; Toronto, Ontario M5G 1X5, Canada (Diamandis)Mount Sinai Hospital; Toronto, Ontario M5G 1X5, Canada (Hoffman), Eleftherios P. Diamandis, MD, PhDLouisiana State University Medical Center; Shreveport, LA 71130-3932 (Yu)Mount Sinai Hospital; Toronto, Ontario M5G 1X5, Canada (Diamandis)Mount Sinai Hospital; Toronto, Ontario M5G 1X5, Canada (Hoffman), and Barry Hoffman, PhDLouisiana State University Medical Center; Shreveport, LA 71130-3932 (Yu)Mount Sinai Hospital; Toronto, Ontario M5G 1X5, Canada (Diamandis)Mount Sinai Hospital; Toronto, Ontario M5G 1X5, Canada (Hoffman)Author, Article, and Disclosure Informationhttps://doi.org/10.7326/0003-4819-131-9-199911020-00023 SectionsAboutFull TextPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissions ShareFacebookTwitterLinkedInRedditEmail TO THE EDITOR:Cauley and colleagues (1) reported that breast cancer risk was elevated not only in white postmenopausal women with high estrogen levels but also in those with high androgen levels. The association of breast cancer risk with androgen has been seen in many epidemiologic studies (2-4), but the mechanism by which androgens contribute to the cause of breast cancer is poorly understood. The relation between androgen and breast cancer is believed to be confounded by the strong correlation between androgen and estrogen because androgen is a precursor of estrogen in its metabolic pathway.
